text: So because of the popularity of Tlaib's books, a lot of people have this idea in their mind that steep corrections in the equity indexes, particularly SPX, but in all the equity indices, people have this idea that it just comes out of nowhere. So we're going along compounding at 7%, 8%, 9% per year or whatever it is. And then all of a sudden, just the world ends and then we're down 50%. And everything that I have looked at, and then also in live trading, there are usually tremors before the earthquake. The problem is, is that most people do not pay attention to them. And this goes back to what I was saying in my earlier point was, this is why I'm so obsessive about measuring realized. Because there's been this thing that has become popularized in the option space that essentially realized doesn't matter. You just trade the implied. The spread between the two is sort of like a futile metric with low efficacy. In actually trading this stuff, I think that couldn't be further from the truth. I think you really need to have, whether it's German class or traditional standard deviation of returns, I think you need different sampling periods. All of that will start to tell you. In some of the worst situations, like let's go back to 2011, with the Eurozone crisis and stuff like that, the intraday ranges, if you were tracking, you're tracking them, were spiking back in May around flash crash time. You started to see expanding ranges, all of a sudden, five day, 10 day realized started spiking, and it was causing like a backwardation on like a realized term structure. And so when those things start to happen, those are your warning signs. Now, a lot of times, especially with zero interest rates and SPED calming of markets, they'll be short lived and you can go back to running your program. But I always take them really seriously. And because of that, I'm always going to take them really seriously. And because of that, I'm always going to take them really seriously. And because of that, I'm always going to take them really seriously. And because of that, I'm always going to take them That I don't have a narrow, a mandate like an investment manager would I don't have a narrow, a mandate like an investment manager would it's during those times, usually it's during those times, usually it's during those times, usually Corey, that I'll actually Corey, that I'll actually Corey, that I'll actually buy the straddle, because I'll start buy the straddle, because I'll start buy the straddle, because I'll start noticing it. And then you have to get noticing it. And then you have to get noticing it. And then you have to get an organized system to try to track all these things, but you'll see where in these short dated tenors, you'll see that the price of the straddle really gets super cheap relative to how much we're moving. Because again, everybody's kind of just complacently in this sort of comatose state where we're just going along. And I'm looking at this and I'm glued at my desk and I'm like, yo, we're moving 80 ES points a day and the straddle is only pricing in like a 23, 25 point move. Why wouldn't you buy it? And you damn sure wouldn't sell it. Although most people just blindly do it, I don't. And so to answer your question, it's just, you have to really pay attention to this stuff and really get granular on the volatility. Because what you'll find is there will be a couple of times every single year on a short vol program that can wipe out all year's profits. If you can just remove one of those or lessen the impact when you do get caught in that situation, that regime shift, then you'll have great risk-efficiency. And that's what I'm talking about. And that's what I'm talking about. You can just do performance. And that's all that matters at the end of the year.
